reviewText: All I got to say is that you need to buy this game. Why? You might ask, well, who wouldn't want to charge into battle, bullets flying everywhere, explosions shaking the screen, screams filling the air. Who wouldn't want to take part in a sandbox war game with hundreds of troops, fighting each other with technology of war. Tanks firing shells at passing jeeps, artillery blowing apart an enemy convoy, squads of troops charging an enemy compund, firing their rifles. This game never gets old. Never. But wait, it doesn't stop there. Hop onto the workshop and change your game into more. Want to hold back hordes of zombies in a post-apocalyptic world? you can do that. Want to defend the shores of Normady as the German during WW2? you can do that. Want to fight as the aliens from Xcom? you can do that. This game is amazing. You need it.

reviewText:
I think it is time that I pay my respect to this game.

For almost forever I have wanted to play a game where I am on the field as a soldier, yet I am able to make tactical decisions changing what the AI focuses on, and RUNNING WITH RIFLES has given me almost exactly that.

In my library this is my second most played game and with good reason. The gameplay is good, the graphics are clean, and the controls well thought out.

First of all the gameplay and AI are something that you will see in the reviews of this game a lot as they really are special and unique. The game is top down at an angle so 3D elements are visible creating an interesting tactical view allowing the player to analyze situations and choose where to move and what to do. Secondly, the cover mechanic in the game is well planned out and doesn't allow players to play like the heroes" they normally play as in call of duty because they will die. Accuracy is another thing as it adds another tactical layer to gaming as shooting while running is very ineffective when compared to crouching giving the positioning of the player (crouching
recommended: or prone) great importance. In RWR

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Online co-op campaign is mayhem.

Huge maps/small maps, grenade launchers/snipers/rocket launchers, artillery strikes/paratroopers, deployable machineguns/cover, boats/tanks/apcs/jeeps. Level up your character, unlock new weapons/vehicles, be able to command a squad. Choose to attack/defend bases. Huge battles. A server with persistant stats. This game is ♥♥♥♥ing awesome, and surprisingly strategic.

If you like top-down shooters, buy it.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: RWR is one of the best indie games i have EVER played. It's also a very mod friendly game, with anyone being able to anything they want with RWR. Well, it's obviously a military game at first glance. You play as three different military factions: The Greenbelts (America), The Graycollars (Germany), and the Brownpants (Russia). But instead of being like most other military shooters such as Call Of Duty of Battlefield, you are not a big action hero soldier sent to the front lines to kill everything that moves, you are a generic low lying foot soldier who is just as expendable and worthless as all your enemies and friends. Every time you die, depending on what faction you are part of, you spawn with a new name that is generated from the bank of first and last names corresponding to said faction. If you are mod savvy, you might know that you can edit this. Because you only take one to two hits to die when not wearing a vest, tactics are a must and can be very rewarding when you plan something out and carry it out correctly. Bases consist of 4 things. #1: The Armory; The armory is a place where you use your currency (RP/Resource Points) you earn throughout the game to purchase new weapons, gadgets, and equipment. You can also sell rare items and weapons scattered throughout the map that you find for some quick cash. You can also deliver enemy weapons to your armory to stock your armory with enemy stuff. This is useful is you want to have some enemy loot that you would otherwise have to go and get from the battle area. Also, some weapons have exp locks. These can't be used until you have a certain amount of exp. You can, however, take the weapons and store them in your backpack for later use.  #2: The Vehicles; the vehicles are an essential part of your advancement to the next objective and can be used as extra firepower against hordes of enemies. #3: The Enemy Objectives; When you capture a base you might notice a large radio tower in the middle of the base. These radio towers are enemy objectives and can be destroyed for quick cash a bit of exp. Specifically, radio towers also block radio calls. This prevents you from calling in reinforcements, armored support, artillery and so on. #4: The Stash; the stash is where you can store extra items to come back to later, but don't let the enemy recapture the base, or the enemy get hold of your powerful stuff! There is ranking system in the game, starting you out as private and ranking you up to higher ranks with more abilities. Higher ranks can use there money to call in artillery, extra troops, deployable cover, and so on. You can earn exp and rank up by killing enemies, as previously mentonied, destroying radio towers, doing side objectives and capturing bases. You might notice the general occasionally saying things like capture that graycollars supply truck to the southwest!". Those are side objectives. Side objectives are things like capturing vehicles and delivering them to the armory for quick cash and exp. There is far too much to this game to talk about in one review
date:
so here is my final verdict:


10/10!
So far no bugs have been found by me (wow!).
An incredible little gem that should get more attention than it already has. Definitley go buy this great game and support the devs!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You guys, and maybe some gals, but mostly guys I'm guessing, remember back when you were little, and had imaginary battles between your little plastic army men?

This is what those imaginary battles looked like. This is that. As a videogame. It's amazing.

Also, this is early access yet one of the most stable games I've played in recent memory. I seriously can't recall any obvious or enjoyment breaking bugs; at worst a few grenade deaths that seemed questionable due to the range between myself and the explosion, but that's it.

reviewText:
This game is a tonful of fun! Whther you are gripping tight to your AK, g36 or m16, its the same awesome feeling of intense firefight all over you. Its damn fast-paced so you better get loving that prone button.
RWR is easy to get a hold of and plays beautifully. There is a fair selection of weapons and i didnt feel like airstrike got too much of a role in game, that meaning it could not be spammed like hell. Its unaccurate, too, so yeah theres that.

I just wonder why you cant change weapons while prone, or shoot bazookas from prone-stance? That might in fact be intentional, but the use of radio sure is not. I didnt get to use radio unless i was crouched.

If you have a frend or few, buy this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ game. It is really fun to play. The campaing could use a little varioation tho. Now its just domination-styled all-around.  Maps are vast and plentiful, from this I am thankful.

TL;DR; Good fast arcadeish top-down shooter, buy it and give them brownpants some reason to soil themselves.

reviewText:
This is a pretty excellent game. It's a hardcore tactical shooter at heart, so cover, positioning, and awareness are vitally important. Also you're going to die. A lot. This is not a forgiving game, which is what makes it so satisfying when you enfilade an enemy position and take out half a dozen soldiers in a few seconds. And then the same thing will happen to you later. It's the circle of life Running With Rifles.

Be aware that the tutorial is butts and there's effectively zero documentation in the game. You will need to go to the wiki to learn most of how the game works. And the wiki is kind of butts too, so you know... good luck. It's worth it, though. My friends and I are having a ton of fun playing a co-op campaign together. Persistent leveling and progress across ten to twenty hours of campaign is a lot of bang for the buck, and that's just one playthrough of one mode.

In summary, if you like hardcore tactical shooters, you'll probably like this game. Buy this ♥♥♥♥. Play it with friends. Accidentally blow yourself up with badly-thrown grenades. That's war, baby.

Welp, this game is amazing.
Why? WELL:

PROS

-Death is very quick
-Fog of War is not a thing (Giving nobody a disadvantage)
-A decent amount on weapons to use
-Vehicles are not overpowered
-You can have up to 10 teamates follow you for SUPER OMEGA KILLING TIME
-The XP system is pretty good (gain on kill, lose on death)

However, this game is not perfect, just near it.

CONS

-There are not that many gamemodes
-It's pretty hard to gain Resource Points sometimes
-Only 3 factions that are not different at all (as far as I can tell)

Overall verdict: 9/10
Buy it now.

reviewText:
Excellent tactical combat potential.  If you're a fan of the Brothers In Arms series, it will probably scratch that itch.  The game is simple, skill-based, potentially very challenging, and fun.  It's easily worth the $15.

My hope is that future patches, DLC, or expansions will expand on this solid baseline.   In-depth squad control and a smarter AI for the squad would be very welcome.   At present, your squad doesn't accomplish much, unfortunately.  But it doesn't detract from the core experience.

Tomorrow I'll be trying out multiplayer...  I've heard nothing but good things, there.

reviewText:
I WOULD LOVE THIS GAME TO DEATH, but I can't, for now, and maybe forever.

There's only one major issue : the multiplayer is DEAD

You can only enjoy the game in solo or online co-op. Nearly all of the servers are empty and no-one is playing PVP if we don't plan an event. This is a ♥♥♥♥ing shame, because the game is new !
The devs haven't designed the game to encourage PVP. They made a wonderful job on every aspects, especially the enemy AI which is one of the best I've seen. But the result is that people don't want to play pvp because they don't like to lose.
Also, maybe the games are too long, the newbies suffer from the absence of a real tutorial or the connections losses/lag, I don't know exactly. But this is a serious problem and the devs are burying their game shamelessly.

I'll be happy to change my appreciation, but for now I'm really disappointed.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nRunning with Rifles is a great game that feels refined and polished despite its current Alpha state. Even playing alone it is easy to waste away hours trying to move through a map and eventually win. Although the biggest feature of this game is the ability to have three factions fighting for dominance on the same map. This mechanic makes for an extremely fun game even if you've been blown up by grenades, mowed down by LMGs, taken out by snipers or even run over by a friendly driving a tank. reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been playing Running With Rifles since at least around beta version 0.71, and so far my experience with the game has been nothing but pure enjoyment.

The game really emphasises the fact that you are but a single unit participating in an all-out, raging war against another, or in some cases more, power. These battles are massive and can see up to 800 AI units participating. You should expect to die.  A lot . To win on a map requires excessive amounts of teamwork between yourself and your teammates from co-ordinating attacks on enemy bases to attacking valuable enemy assets.

Luckily, the AI is pretty competent at doing so and should not be underestimated. You will find yourself flanked by the enemy AI and urged to run from cover due to enemy grenades. You will need to keep your head down most of the time, too. The AI's accuracy is not to be trifled with. To beat the AI, you'll need to help your team by providing resources, particularly men and firepower.

The remarkable thing about this game is that dying isn't annoying as you would expect it to. You will get used to dying quickly and instead will be eager to jump right back into a fight. The fight will always be going on, whether you are there or not. You can choose where to go. It is an open-world, albeit a very dangerous one.

And it doesn't stop there. The game, even while it is still being developed and will be seeing new features, sees modding present already. Creating your own faction is relatively simple. I can play a map and war between 5 different powers thanks to some simple modding and content provided by the modding community.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early Access Review:

Running with Rifles is a game I truly enjoyed, this is game is $10 well spent.

For those who enjoy tactical shooters, team-based shooters and FPS games, this is definitely for you.

RWR at first doesn't seem to be a game that take itself seriously, when you see it, you'll probably think this is a casual shooter that you just run and gun and everything along your path just dies, but as you play the game more, you'll realize how complex(yet easy to pick up) the mechanics of this game is.

RWR is very straight forward, you spawn in a very big open map, where you can go anywhere at anytime at your own will, in the middle of a huge war, and I mean HUGE, i'm talking about hundreds of soldiers, both friendlies and hostiles shooting and slinging bombs at each other. You're this soldier who has to fight for your faction, but you're just any other soldier, you're not a hero, you're not Rambo, or John Matrix or Master Chief, or James Ramirez, you're cannon fodder. You're not expendable, you're disposable. The game gives you the feeling of a regular soldier in the middle of the battlefield. Being a hero and a lonewolf is possible, and it does reward  you greatly, but teamwork as a squad and as an army is the key to victory.

Controls are simple, if you're familiar with the usual WASD FPS or action games, it's very similar. Combat though is very team-based and tactical focused, you can make your team go for gold while you cover their attack, or as your team covers you, You alone can attack from behind to flush down the enemies as your team cover fires. The AI of the game is pretty smart, both in strategy and in combat. The cover system of the game is very nicely done as well. This is those games that you can't just go guns a blazing and come back alive(well you can, but definitely expect to die a lot).

Other than the straight-up battles of the war, you can also form a small squad(or go lone wolf, your choice) to do some covert missions, spot enemy vehicles, crates and even do sabotage missions of your own which greatly rewards you.

There is a simple RPG mechanic in the game as well where you gain XP as you kill enemy troops and do missions which ranks you up to gain more troops in your squad and vehicle rights, this also features an inventory system which you can pick up gear and  weapons to help you in your war, other than that, you also unlock special weapons as you progress,

Being a top-down shooter, they've actually done a pretty good job with the camera view as well, instead of the usual you face where you point" kind of camera
date: they made the crosshair/pointer your point of view. The camera moves where you position your crosshair as it gives you vulnerabilty behind. It's fair in multiplayer as you can do sneaky stealth attacks from behind when an enemy is facing the other way and vice versa.\n\nRunning with Rifles also has a unique visual charm compared to it's peers of the genre. Other than the usual realistic graphics that's been a genre standard
hoursPlayed: such as Armed and Dangerous
voteText: Battlefield Heroes

votesHelpful: subtle cell-shaded graphics. The speech bubbles also adds to the charm
votesTotal: especially when your squad complains who farted in the APC. This lessens the grim and scary feeling of war
votesFunny: but the battle prolongs and the bodies pile up

The max capacity for a server is 40.\n\nMaybe the only downside I can see as of the moment in this game is the lack of sounds. I'd like to hear more war-ish and battlefield-ish sounds

reviewText:
You'll start a battle as one person, and end as a different one.
Not just literally - you'll end up dying so many times that you'll forget the name of the soldier you started with - but also physically, in the real world, as well.
I'm writing this right now after completing the Battle of Keepsake Bay.  I've seen other reviews and comments from different people who described how long it took them - the most I've seen so far was 7 hours.  Seven hours.  It took me three and a half, personally, but my God.  This is just an amazing game.  It was so frustrating, yet so rewarding when I won.
Basically, each map is the same idea.  You start off playing as your respective faction, and you need to conquer the map.  Each landmark you need to capture is highlighted on the map, and typically, your faction has a specific order to follow in terms of capturing them.  But it's not as simple as kill all the enemies, take the landmark, and move on.  No, the AI is ridiculously intelligent - and they never stop respawning.  But neither does your side - and they're just as smart.  The result?  A well-built stalemate generator.  A few maps were easy to beat, but a couple - like the one I listed above - were nightmares.  Run out to the front, take cover, and just spray bullets downrange, clipping as many enemies as possible, while at the same time, avoiding their bullets.  One side captures the landmark.  Their counter-attack overwhelms you, and they take it back.  Repeat.  Repeat.  Repeat.  This can literally go on for hours - you need to use some real strategy and command your squad to get anything done.  Respawn.  Repeat.  It's insane, but amazing at the same time.  And once the battle is over, and you've won: it shows.  Blood covering every street, bodies all over the place, burnt out APC's and cars, craters from explosions.

Aside from the extremely addicting gameplay, this game is quite good in other respects.  The art style is really damn charming: the quirky graphics, combined with gameplay, remind me of the old Army Men games made by 3DO.  The sound work is fantastic - I'd like to see, in the future, maybe some music during the actual gameplay?  The title/menu music gets stuck in your head, but I like it.  Everything from explosions, to bullets whizzing by, even to people climbing fences - it sounds great all around.  The RPG elements are subtle, but they really make the game so much better - and addicting.  I like the system of trading items or weapons you find for points - which you buy more weapons with.  Big selection in terms of guns.  It's easy to rank up once you get a hang of the game, but the perks make you feel like you're actually accomplishing something - bigger squad size, the ability to take over friendly vehicles and command them, and calling in support make you want to try and rank up.

I think the biggest upshot to this game is how well it was done for an early-access indie game.  I have never seen anything like it - I only bought it recently, but apparently the developers kept it updated frequently over the course of a couple of years, always keeping players in the loop, and now, they've just hit full release.  That, coupled with the fact that it's got a demo to go along with it - that's what really hooked me in.  I played 15 minutes of the demo, and bought it immediately.  And I have no regrets.

Great work.  This game is a solid ten in my book.

This has to be one of the most satisfying war game experiences I've ever played and the fact that it's a quite simple top down shooter makes it all the more satisfying. In the campaign mode the maps are linked and the free form nature of it means I know I'll be coming back to it time and time again. One of those games that when you're looking at your game library unsure of what you want to be playing, you'll always just say What the hell" and jump into RWR.

I've only had a little time in multiplayer though it was also just as satisfying. I don't normally bother with the review process but I think this crowd is on to a winner

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is fun. Some reviews and discussions about this game may degrade this fact or state that I am false but I have seen a pattern in the bad reviews. They all say the game is too hard, too easy to die in  and the AI is unfair. There first point is just ... foolish. Dark souls, demon souls and the other are supposed to be hard but people love that game and this game is designed to make you just 1 out of 100s of generic soldiers on the battle field fighting, protecting and destroying objectives. Yes the game is challenging(just look at the difficulty options, less hard and hard) but that is why there is cover to protect you from dieing and the intelligent AI on your side to either be meat shields and protectors. The third point, AI is unfair, if find hard to believe because I haven't found anything unfair about the AI! Plus, you can edit the AI settings, their accuracy, how many of them there are. You can make it to where you're the unfair one!
Positive things about the game are the wide variety of weapons, intellegent AI, great maps that range in size, amazing community and developers that respond to player suggestions and questions. I could explain every bit I just listed but I know you wouldn't read most of it. One thing is simple.... This game is Amazingly Fun and Challenging.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nRUNNING WITH RIFLES or RWR is a top down tactical shooter with Rpg elements that has a lot of things that make it individual compared to other games in its genre It brings the carnage, intensity, feel and stress of the second world war right onto your computer monitor, Not only is it a video game but also a visual representation of the amount of soldiers that would die during a typical WW2 battle. with blood sometimes completely covering the ground of a high traffic area in a battlefield the game also shows how easy it was to die in a battle of that time period the game brings in good physics, addictive play, lagless graphics that preform amazingly with graphics maxed out and lots of units on the screen. This game also shows the overal size of WW2 battlefields with options allowing you to change the amount of soldier on the battlefield ranging from a couple handfuls to large scale invasions of hundreds of men and with 3 armys to choose from green,grey and brown the battles will never get boring with great audio graphics and gameplay and squad control I give this game a 9.5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've followed this game for a while now and in all honesty, it's been a great roadtrip. The game itself for £11 or £7 as i write this review, is more than worth the asking price as in return you are getting a fun, strategic shooter that combines elements from nintendo games such as cannon fodder along side the scales of battles from the Total War franchise. The devs are highly active on the community pages and the game is never left 'dead' at any given time with updates being worked on throughout the weeks. I have had nothing but fun playing this game online, coop and single player, each providing a different experience each time with a ton of replayability. I encourage you to try it for yourself with the free demo provided on the RWR website and buy the game in the future as it deserves more publicity than the mainstream **** that is clogging the store at the moment.

Pros - Huge Ai battles, like seriously huge.
3 individual armies with unique weapons/looks
Multiple ways of playing
Coop/online with bots
Wide range of weapons and vehicles
Radio supports such as paratroopers, mortar strikes, artillery and vehicle drops
Small miniboss' with unique loot/weapons
massive maps all unique
Different Game modes
Deployable and static emplacements to build fortifications
Helpful Ai

Cons (not really the correct term) -
You will die alot due to Ai, but hey it's a war
Some Ai vehicle drivers can get stuck and frustrate you
Not all Ai will charge enemy positions meaning you will need to do alot of work in order to win
Some missions can be hard especiall by yourself (end mission for greycollars) PLAY WITH FRIENDS!

Apart from those minor, and i mean minor, 'cons' this game is great and i look forward to the next updates to see what will be added next, especially as the devs are open to ideas from the fans!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
You'll start a battle as one person, and end as a different one.
Not just literally - you'll end up dying so many times that you'll forget the name of the soldier you started with - but also physically, in the real world, as well.
I'm writing this right now after completing the Battle of Keepsake Bay.  I've seen other reviews and comments from different people who described how long it took them - the most I've seen so far was 7 hours.  Seven hours.  It took me three and a half, personally, but my God.  This is just an amazing game.  It was so frustrating, yet so rewarding when I won.
Basically, each map is the same idea.  You start off playing as your respective faction, and you need to conquer the map.  Each landmark you need to capture is highlighted on the map, and typically, your faction has a specific order to follow in terms of capturing them.  But it's not as simple as kill all the enemies, take the landmark, and move on.  No, the AI is ridiculously intelligent - and they never stop respawning.  But neither does your side - and they're just as smart.  The result?  A well-built stalemate generator.  A few maps were easy to beat, but a couple - like the one I listed above - were nightmares.  Run out to the front, take cover, and just spray bullets downrange, clipping as many enemies as possible, while at the same time, avoiding their bullets.  One side captures the landmark.  Their counter-attack overwhelms you, and they take it back.  Repeat.  Repeat.  Repeat.  This can literally go on for hours - you need to use some real strategy and command your squad to get anything done.  Respawn.  Repeat.  It's insane, but amazing at the same time.  And once the battle is over, and you've won: it shows.  Blood covering every street, bodies all over the place, burnt out APC's and cars, craters from explosions.

Aside from the extremely addicting gameplay, this game is quite good in other respects.  The art style is really damn charming: the quirky graphics, combined with gameplay, remind me of the old Army Men games made by 3DO.  The sound work is fantastic - I'd like to see, in the future, maybe some music during the actual gameplay?  The title/menu music gets stuck in your head, but I like it.  Everything from explosions, to bullets whizzing by, even to people climbing fences - it sounds great all around.  The RPG elements are subtle, but they really make the game so much better - and addicting.  I like the system of trading items or weapons you find for points - which you buy more weapons with.  Big selection in terms of guns.  It's easy to rank up once you get a hang of the game, but the perks make you feel like you're actually accomplishing something - bigger squad size, the ability to take over friendly vehicles and command them, and calling in support make you want to try and rank up.

I think the biggest upshot to this game is how well it was done for an early-access indie game.  I have never seen anything like it - I only bought it recently, but apparently the developers kept it updated frequently over the course of a couple of years, always keeping players in the loop, and now, they've just hit full release.  That, coupled with the fact that it's got a demo to go along with it - that's what really hooked me in.  I played 15 minutes of the demo, and bought it immediately.  And I have no regrets.

Great work.  This game is a solid ten in my book.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nExtremely entertaining. Many shooter games put you in the role of the action hero; able to take and deal out a seemingly infinite amount of bullets. RWR, however, forces you to become a soldier just like all others, with a fragile body and imperfect aim. With this seemingly meaningless soldier, however, you can have tremendous impact. Sneaking into enemy bases, calling airstrikes, you name it; one man can have an impact. Whether RWR is a social commentary on the shooter's depiction of a player, or simply an extremely difficult shooter, this game is money well spent.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early Access Review:

Running with Rifles is a game I truly enjoyed, this is game is $10 well spent.

For those who enjoy tactical shooters, team-based shooters and FPS games, this is definitely for you.

RWR at first doesn't seem to be a game that take itself seriously, when you see it, you'll probably think this is a casual shooter that you just run and gun and everything along your path just dies, but as you play the game more, you'll realize how complex(yet easy to pick up) the mechanics of this game is.

RWR is very straight forward, you spawn in a very big open map, where you can go anywhere at anytime at your own will, in the middle of a huge war, and I mean HUGE, i'm talking about hundreds of soldiers, both friendlies and hostiles shooting and slinging bombs at each other. You're this soldier who has to fight for your faction, but you're just any other soldier, you're not a hero, you're not Rambo, or John Matrix or Master Chief, or James Ramirez, you're cannon fodder. You're not expendable, you're disposable. The game gives you the feeling of a regular soldier in the middle of the battlefield. Being a hero and a lonewolf is possible, and it does reward  you greatly, but teamwork as a squad and as an army is the key to victory.

Controls are simple, if you're familiar with the usual WASD FPS or action games, it's very similar. Combat though is very team-based and tactical focused, you can make your team go for gold while you cover their attack, or as your team covers you, You alone can attack from behind to flush down the enemies as your team cover fires. The AI of the game is pretty smart, both in strategy and in combat. The cover system of the game is very nicely done as well. This is those games that you can't just go guns a blazing and come back alive(well you can, but definitely expect to die a lot).

Other than the straight-up battles of the war, you can also form a small squad(or go lone wolf, your choice) to do some covert missions, spot enemy vehicles, crates and even do sabotage missions of your own which greatly rewards you.

There is a simple RPG mechanic in the game as well where you gain XP as you kill enemy troops and do missions which ranks you up to gain more troops in your squad and vehicle rights, this also features an inventory system which you can pick up gear and  weapons to help you in your war, other than that, you also unlock special weapons as you progress,

Being a top-down shooter, they've actually done a pretty good job with the camera view as well, instead of the usual you face where you point" kind of camera
date: they made the crosshair/pointer your point of view. The camera moves where you position your crosshair as it gives you vulnerabilty behind. It's fair in multiplayer as you can do sneaky stealth attacks from behind when an enemy is facing the other way and vice versa.\n\nRunning with Rifles also has a unique visual charm compared to it's peers of the genre. Other than the usual realistic graphics that's been a genre standard
hoursPlayed: such as Armed and Dangerous

reviewText:
After playing this game to death on Desura, before the Steam release, I somewhat forgot about it, despite thoroughly enjoying it. Was very pleased to see it's seen continued development and a Steam release.

The game's a fairly casual, top down shooter, with relatively hardcore mechanics. Think of it as Arma Lite. Bullets are deadly, explosive and vehicles are deadlier. Tactics and coordination are a must in order to advance. Squad mechanics work well, and the AI is competent and deadly, indeed. There's a wide variety of weapons and vehicles to utilise, including rifles, LMGs, shotguns, explosives and APCs, as well as a handfull of fun gamemodes, as well as mod support.

I hope the multiplayer community grows further, as I feel this game could really shine as a nice pick-up and play squad based shooter.

Graphics and sound are good, whilst 'basic'. The style is reminiscent of good old green army men toys. Particle effects like explosions and muzzle flair are nice, and punch up the 'toy' style.

Overall if you want a fun top-down to jump into every once in a while, but still enjoy some of the depth you'd get from it's bigger cousins, this game is a must.

reviewText:
I'm going to keep this snappy

Pros:
Excellent Infantry AI that uses Sqad Formations, Flanking and knows how to apply their weapons effectively.

Great Balance, No gun is Too overpowered, LMGs are heavy to deploy but hard to unroot once activated. Assault Rifles are good all rounders, Snipers are good, but the top down perspective makes them awkward to handle nad Shotguns are often too situational for effective use on a majority of occasions.

Good selection Weapons, Aks, G36Cs, M16s are available to their respective factions and stealing them from opponents grants them for your faction (but only temporarily for some reason)

Great choices of gameplay: Do you want to be a lone wolf? Grab a Sniper Rifle and some C4 and cause soem behind the lines enemy havoc! Or maybe get a tactical squad of troops and outflank adn annihilate your opponents with superior tactics and firepower, And if you want to participate in mass attacks as a part of the cogs of your faction! Theres a role for any one and any skill level.

Great Variety of maps, from Holiday resorts to intense Middle Eastern Urban Combat, a Harsh Winter Trench Combat.

A slew of mods are already present for the games, Halo? (If you really want that,... just kidding ;)) XCOM? sure! there is a strong mod support for this game and for its 10 pound value, it gives a metric ton of replay value on top of the content available.

Negatives:
Ai for Driving and Swimming is dumb, like really dumb, they have already poked fun at the poor driving with some dialogue between troops but they need to patch this, I have been run over mid Rocket Aiming by incompetent drivers after incompetent driver and swimming Ai are easier to shoot than Fish In a barrel, In fact fish in a barrel would have a better survival rate than one of these troopers swimming!

Endgame missions feel unbalanced, the Base assault/defense mission is perhaps a bit too much of a difficulty spike, but is still doable, but the Stealth Mission where you take out Radio Towers is really lack luster, the stealth feels finicky at this moment and could benefit from some form of back up or stealth gadgets such as Radar or Smoke grenades.

Factions lack distinct styles
Theire are
Grey Collars: German forces
Green Belts: America
Brownpants: Russia (poor Russia, a pun for defecation :P)
Aside from a slight model change they play identically, the only distinct change is the American Jeep as a wider fire range for passengers, but less Cover for their passengers. I think there needs to be a mroe distinct change, for example perhaps Germany should have the hmore Accurate Weapons, the Russians the Most damaging and America the Highest Fire Rate?

idk, perhaps that would imbalance the game too much.
Also the maps seem to vary in style and gameplay, but the environments themself are not distinct aside From the Winter outfits in FridgeValley, there is not much change between maps like Black Gold Estuary or Rattlesnake Crescent.


But those are only minor and easily fixable flaws of a solid and completely brilliant game!
8.5/10

9/10 after AI fixes

its only 10 Pounds yet its worth nearly every penny,if you find yourself in a good need for an Interesting Over the top Military Top down shooter (must be a huge market there! :P)

Then you would have to be nuts to not get Running With Rifles (You'd also have to be nuts to start Running with rifles, if you catch my drift, please don't take that out of context)

reviewText:
I've had the game since Alpha and followed the progression. The game has a solid campaign with a big overview map and a last boss map. You can play these maps over and over and try different routes and tactics.

I've played mostly Coop so I can't speak for the PVP part, which I don't like. Against the NPC and AI, the game is like a single player experience except you can have friends help you out and push. PVP is a different story because you can't hide in grass and if you see your enemy, they most likely see you.

There's 2 combat vehicles for all teams which is an APC and a tank. You can have a HMMW flown in which is not part of the team's assets.

The game uses RP points as currency for buying weapons and assets which is a solid balanced currency. Most enemies drop RP worthy loot upon death and you recover these items and sell them. Gaining RP is also fairly easy, just stay in a capture zone and kill enemies.

One thing to note about the combat is that there is no health system in the game. Each gun has a probability to hit at a certain range and if it goes past 100%, the target dies. In order to prevent death, units can wear body armor which gives 2 chances of surviving a hit and a third which puts the unit down for a medic.

Pros and cons:
+ 32 player servers where each player can have a maximum of ten AI squad mates which allows for 320 units of in game units for a team + the stationary AI units that defend points.
+ Large variety of weapons and balance.
+ Large maps with close quarters.
+ Lengthy battles (one map can last 4 hours).
+ Cartoon style.
+ Good performance with 32 players.

- Unlimited tickets for teams (Yes, this is a con, after killing 300 waves of enemies that can't be halted it gets tedious).
- No smoke grenades or deployable smoke screen.
- APCs and Tanks looses health from grenades.
- Somewhat rage inducing.

The game looks cheesy but it's very fun and very serious.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've followed this game for a while now and in all honesty, it's been a great roadtrip. The game itself for £11 or £7 as i write this review, is more than worth the asking price as in return you are getting a fun, strategic shooter that combines elements from nintendo games such as cannon fodder along side the scales of battles from the Total War franchise. The devs are highly active on the community pages and the game is never left 'dead' at any given time with updates being worked on throughout the weeks. I have had nothing but fun playing this game online, coop and single player, each providing a different experience each time with a ton of replayability. I encourage you to try it for yourself with the free demo provided on the RWR website and buy the game in the future as it deserves more publicity than the mainstream **** that is clogging the store at the moment.

Pros - Huge Ai battles, like seriously huge.
3 individual armies with unique weapons/looks
Multiple ways of playing
Coop/online with bots
Wide range of weapons and vehicles
Radio supports such as paratroopers, mortar strikes, artillery and vehicle drops
Small miniboss' with unique loot/weapons
massive maps all unique
Different Game modes
Deployable and static emplacements to build fortifications
Helpful Ai

Cons (not really the correct term) -
You will die alot due to Ai, but hey it's a war
Some Ai vehicle drivers can get stuck and frustrate you
Not all Ai will charge enemy positions meaning you will need to do alot of work in order to win
Some missions can be hard especiall by yourself (end mission for greycollars) PLAY WITH FRIENDS!

Apart from those minor, and i mean minor, 'cons' this game is great and i look forward to the next updates to see what will be added next, especially as the devs are open to ideas from the fans!

Overall, get the game. I see myself playing this one for a while.

reviewText: As Lieutenant Christopher Obama dying gaze settled on that of his faithful subordinate, Pvt. Ted Bundy, he said in a voice choked with blood and agony press space to continue"\n\nThis is a fantastic little game. To sum it up briefly
date: you play one of the expendable extras in a huge battle scene. The difficulty is quite hard to manage at first
recommended: and I'm not necessarily sold on the whole top-down camera angle
hoursPlayed: but if you persist
voteText: you'll find a cover system that is intuitive and easy to use and a hugely enjoyable combat system. As you play
helpfulPercent: you acquire experience which translates into promotions to higher ranks which allow you to control larger and larger squads as well as unlocking new weapons
votesHelpful: equipment and support calls. This is an excellent way of gradually introducing new game concepts to new players. It's quite rewarding to finally make it to the point where you have a large squad following you as you
votesTotal: well armed and armored
votesFunny: sweep through huge mobs of enemies.\n\nThat said
commentsCount: a few things stop this game from reaching its true potential. You don't get to keep your rank across campaigns or different servers
column16: making the effort of progression feel somewhat futile. I wouldn't object to resetting rank as an option in campaigns and servers because you can rank up very fast if you're doing well
column17: but it would be nice to have a rank
column18: and unlocks that you could carry across multiple singleplayer games
column19: for one's own enjoyment. It strikes me that this game is meant for patient players who value a sense of delayed gratification
column20:
and I think most who fit into that category would appreciate some sense of tangible reward for their efforts outside of just the match they're in.

It would also be nice if the game would adopt the steam workshop as many wonderful mods for this game exist but can be hard to track down.

TLDR 4/5
Pros
-solid gameplay
-good sense of humor
-devs still seem to update

Cons
-loss of rank/equipment progress at end of campaigns and switching servers
-potentially aggravating for people with little patience"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Definitely worth $15 but I got lucky and got it for $10 from a sale.

The game is incredibly entertaining and deep regardless of its apparant simplicity of UI and graphics. The graphics are a sort of smoothed / voxel shaded look that reminds me a tad of borderlands and a certain Wolfire Worlds tech demo I saw a while ago. They look very nice from my point of view and I like what the artists have done.

As far as gameplay goes, many of the other reviewers here seem to be comparing it to battlefield and I can't help but agree with them- at least to some extent. The game is a sort of isometric warzone where you control one soldier and can gain rank by killing enemy soldiers and doing special objectives (like capturing an enemy supply truck, which has other effects other than just exp). As you gain rank you gain access to more weapons: unlike other games though these weapons arent necessarily just upgrades- they all fill some form of role and if you want to do everything you won't be able to find one weapon that satisfies all criteria. However, you also gain the ability to lead around some of your fellow AI soldiers into battle in a squad for every 1000 exp (up to a maximum of 10). With the combination of extra weapons available to your character and extra soldiers available to lead you can become quite the force on the battlefield, even when a normal battle can have anywhere from 100 to 800 soldiers active. While 800 soldiers may sound like a lot, and it certainly is, the maps are still fairly large- with what I figure was 2-300 soldiers there were battles all across of anywhere from 20-40 troops during the campaign, which at 7 hours in I have yet to finish (though that is partially my own fault, as I believe I failed to help my allies a few too many times and we got completely pushed back from about 6 points across the map- essentially right back to our base).

Another nice thing is that, even though the game is isometric, your view of the world has both positives and negatives. To allow your to make use of varying ranges on weapons there is a sort of camera tug" that follows your crosshairs instead of just centering your view on your character. The benefit is being able to see far ahead
date: like you would normally be able to if it was first-person
recommended: while the downside is the possibility of being flanked far more easily because you can't see your character at all anymore if you are using some longer-ranged weaponry. Shorter ranged weapons still have some slight downsides in that all weapons have ranges greater than you can normally see when you are centered on your character
hoursPlayed:
and so if you get flanked you won't necessarily see that you have been until you are already being shot at.


Overall
voteText: the game is enjoyable and I am having a lot of fun. Here are some overall pointers for those of you who just want some quick info :\n+ Well-done UI that aims for ease of use and readability while being unobtrusive\n+ Decently replayable as no battle will be the same
helpfulPercent:
especially in multiplayer
+ Graphics are also well done and I personally really enjoy the aesthetic
+ Lots of options (tactically)- the maps are all very open and large
+ With 10 soldiers following you at the higher ranks you can definitely change how the battle plays out
+ You can change the battle even being a lone soldier if you are a good shot


- Driving AI could use some work it seems but is otherwise solid
- Early Access at the time of this review
votesHelpful: current state is easily release-worthy though (minus the driving AI
votesTotal: of course)\n- There honestly isn't much I dislike about this game
votesFunny: easily worth the money"

reviewText:
Grade: A   If you don't want to read this pros and cons are below.

Really good game. Multiplayer is active and fun. Is realistic in it's own way.  It does have a slight learning curve at first but once you get the general idea of what you are doing it is really fun. You can command an AI controlled squad once you reach the rank of Corporal (1000 XP) You lose xp upon death and gain xp upon kills.  You gain RP to purchase and use options in your radio (Not available until the rank of Corporal)  Vehicles include, tanks, APC, troop transports, jeeps, dune buggy with a mounted machine gun,  spawn vehicles, and armory vehicles . You fight for territory on large maps over objectives.  Armory includes anything from C4, Rockets, MachineGuns, Rifles, Mortors, Turrets , Riot Shields , Grenades (Flash Bangs, Hand Grenade, Impact Grenades) , body armor (EOD Suits, Bullet proof vests) .  The AI is very smart so playing alone in single player and co-op is fun if you're are not into PVP . The radio: Call  reinforcements , artillery,  Sandbags for cover (Also in the Armory) ,  vehicles.  I'm sure there are more things I prolly left out but this is the basics of it. If you buy, you more than likely will enjoy it.  The only thing is , the ladders on buildings can be a bit buggy sometimes other than that, everything rocks. The graphics are very enjoyable too.

Pros- No voice chat
Extremely fun
Active Multiplayer
Lots of Weapons
Lots of Vehicles
Large Maps.
All Factions can fight on single map.
Taking cover and firing system is great.
Realistic.
A toaster can run this.
Friendly Community.

Cons- No voice chat
buggy ladders (sometimes)
Tutorial doesn't help much.

reviewText:
I've had the game since Alpha and followed the progression. The game has a solid campaign with a big overview map and a last boss map. You can play these maps over and over and try different routes and tactics.

I've played mostly Coop so I can't speak for the PVP part, which I don't like. Against the NPC and AI, the game is like a single player experience except you can have friends help you out and push. PVP is a different story because you can't hide in grass and if you see your enemy, they most likely see you.

There's 2 combat vehicles for all teams which is an APC and a tank. You can have a HMMW flown in which is not part of the team's assets.

The game uses RP points as currency for buying weapons and assets which is a solid balanced currency. Most enemies drop RP worthy loot upon death and you recover these items and sell them. Gaining RP is also fairly easy, just stay in a capture zone and kill enemies.

One thing to note about the combat is that there is no health system in the game. Each gun has a probability to hit at a certain range and if it goes past 100%, the target dies. In order to prevent death, units can wear body armor which gives 2 chances of surviving a hit and a third which puts the unit down for a medic.

Pros and cons:
+ 32 player servers where each player can have a maximum of ten AI squad mates which allows for 320 units of in game units for a team + the stationary AI units that defend points.
+ Large variety of weapons and balance.
+ Large maps with close quarters.
+ Lengthy battles (one map can last 4 hours).
+ Cartoon style.
+ Good performance with 32 players.

- Unlimited tickets for teams (Yes, this is a con, after killing 300 waves of enemies that can't be halted it gets tedious).
- No smoke grenades or deployable smoke screen.
- APCs and Tanks looses health from grenades.
- Somewhat rage inducing.

The game looks cheesy but it's very fun and very serious.

reviewText: A hidden treat of a game. The advertisement blurb does it justice. A top down shooter might not seem like something with deep combat, but the beauty of it is just that. No 'health', getting shot means death. However - the way this works is very interesting compared to other games of this. It means there is a CHANCE to be killed, and the chance varies between weapons / ranges. In this case, let's look at a shotgun. Close range one pellet is almost gaurenteed to kill you, long range you'll see a bloodsplat and nothing else. It's beyond comprehension at first but is forgiving as well as I suppose comparatively realistic. Although this may sound like you won't be dying a lot, believe me, you will die.\nAdd on the new steam workshop, and you've got a heck of a time!

reviewText: I dont often write reviews, and If I even do write one its short and sweet. but RWR has a special place in my heart, so it deserves a longer review then what I usually give. There are many things that people may not like about RWR, the fact that its top down only, the fact that it has a semi-steep learning curve and the fact that the game itself is very hard and require's either a group of friends to play with or a good team. but desptie all of that it is a GOOD GAME! their are currently problems with lag and desync on almost all of the servers ( I havent found a single server that doesnt lag or desync just a LITTLE bit yet ) but if you can put that aside its a good game, I would reccomend buying it while its on sale or when you know your going to have lots of extra money.

reviewText:
This is a great game, and it makes me really sad that the developers can't put more money into marketing.

Putting that aside, graphically, I have no problem with this game. Textures seem to be alright, although they won't really make any difference in game play.

The game play itself can get very intense. Every death matters greatly and playing single player on a harder difficulties makes that aspect of the game even more enjoyable. As for multiplayer, one can spend hours just playing a single match and still be as engaged as when they started. Granted, this game will not give you any easy wins so don't go in expecting to gain something big every single playtime. You won't need to worry about the AI as they are superb and are the real backbone of the entire game.

Overall this game is great if you are open minded to different game genres, it has great replay value, and for the price it it's a steal. That being said, if you aren't willing to spend hours on end for one single match (which is still really fun btw) then this might not be the game for you.

P.S: If you do get the game, make sure to find a friend who is willing to get it as well.

reviewText:
Best. Strategy. Ever.

*Creates Running in the Trenches(mod) game with max soldiers and all factions*
*Plays as Britain*
-Starts game-
For some reason britain's invading the Red army

Britain has only one base so all the soldiers run up the hill

*Massive carnage ensues, Estimated around 30-60 casualties from Britain in the first 10 seconds alone*
Le me: Commands squad to get behind cover at a fallen tree, while I set up machine gun behind rock

*Mortar strike comes*
*Decimates half the hill*

All the NPCs respawn, and we try this again.

After about 5 minutes the air is full with bullets and you can die by simply being alive, with artillery strikes, hordes of charging russians, and ♥♥♥♥♥ too many Machinegunners. Also, so many elite soldiers have died now that there's so many rare items on the ground there's more than actual common items.

*Finally gets promoted to Colonel with its massive RP boost*
*Orders 10 artillery strikes on Russian hill*
(Keep in mind we haven't even taken one territory yet (That's the hill!))

*Russians die*

We finally take the hill after like, 100,000 casualties and 50 lives for me.


420/69 would install mod to make PTSD Great war edition.

reviewText: A hidden treat of a game. The advertisement blurb does it justice. A top down shooter might not seem like something with deep combat, but the beauty of it is just that. No 'health', getting shot means death. However - the way this works is very interesting compared to other games of this. It means there is a CHANCE to be killed, and the chance varies between weapons / ranges. In this case, let's look at a shotgun. Close range one pellet is almost gaurenteed to kill you, long range you'll see a bloodsplat and nothing else. It's beyond comprehension at first but is forgiving as well as I suppose comparatively realistic. Although this may sound like you won't be dying a lot, believe me, you will die.\nAdd on the new steam workshop, and you've got a heck of a time!

reviewText:
Introduction: Holy ♥♥♥♥. Only 8 hours of this game and I ♥♥♥♥ing love it. There is no other way to say it. I love this game as if it were part of my family. This is one of the best games I have ever played.

What I like about this game: There is barely anywhere to start. For one, I love the large scale battles. You can either choose to use tactics, or just go guns blazing. There is a vast array of weaponry and gear to use, and lots of vehicles to choose from. I personally really like the radio calls. You can call mortar and artillery support, you can call for airborne reinforcements, and so much more. The battles are very balanced, for me at least.

Problems: There aren't any problems I've ran into. No glitches, nothing is unfair, there isn't anything wrong with this game.

Conclusion: Should I get this game? Hell yes, you will love it.

reviewText:
tl;dr If you're willing to adapt to the challenges and learn the lessons of RWR then I recommend it wholeheartedly. If you struggle (or are unwilling) to adapt to challenges then this will only annoy you.

RWR is an amazingly simple and intuitive concept masterfully executed. You are just another soldier on a battlefield filled with soldiers and you will die as easily as any other soldier

Where most games today simply reward you for progression RWR punishes you for making mistakes. You will die often and maybe even become frustrated. But you will soon figure out what a mistake is and realize that you can avoid making those mistakes if you focus.

If you're patient and carefully execute sound plans then you will be rewarded with a sense of satisfaction that very few games are capable of providing. You are just one guy on a massive battlefield and can very easily have little effect on the world around you.

After playing a while, when my mind started to tire, I had a tendency to start rushing or not to consider my actions properly; those were the times that the enemy pushed forward and if I was lucky, I would only be stranded on the wrong side of enemy lines.

It makes me feel human and fragile. It made me feel many things: good and bad but all of it positive. Most AAA titles I see are like candy: tasty but expensive and shallow. RWR is a solid meal of beef and vegetable stew that nourishes the mind and body and forces both to grow. Going to play it over and over again in the years to come.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I believe an hour is good enough to make the claim that this game is everything it says it is.  With that said, I feel it has the potential to be one of the better games on steam because it's unique -- different.  This might scare some people, but those who are adventures and enjoy a modern-ish-esque shooter from a top-down perspective (kinda,) then this will give you a lot of joy for 10 bucks.

Pro's are:

-Cover system is automatic, and easy to work with.
-AI is pretty friggen smart.  I mean they can detect when they're about to hit something when they drive (most of the time :P)
-Mutliplayer (when there is) is a blast.  This game is 10x better with friends.
-Strategy gets you far, even sneaking about can get you around enemy lines.  They won't notice!
-UI is great!  There's not a lot on the screen which allows you too see more.
-The Main Menu screen is like a tutorial -- you can move your soldier around and test weapons, driving, cover, etc.
-More things I can't think of!

Con's are:
-Sometimes it's hard to tell if you're on higher or lower terrain.  AI can sense this, which throws the balance off a bit. KEYWORD: Sometimes.  Though this can be adjusted a bit in the options menu.


Suggestions:.  Steam Workshop with an Editor, and Steam Server support.  These would ensure that the game stays alive for a long time.

RwR is definitely a game I'll be playing in the future for a while to come.

reviewText: Running With Rifles is like regular war only in order to gain the ability to call artillery strikes and get better equipment, you have to salvage horny magazines and booze.\n\nRWR is an RPG-style top-down shooter. Your mission is to take over enemy territory until you are the only faction with territory left on the map. Pretty straight-forward, but it's easier said than done. If you're playing with vanilla settings (the way it should be), you'll find that going rambo like in all those other games won't work. At all. Working with all the other soldiers in the army is absolutely necessary if you want to succeed. You'll start as a grunt; not much more than cannon fodder. But as you learn the mechanics of the game and start killing off more than 2 troops a life, you'll gain ranks and soon, you can command your own squadron. When you get here, you won't need to follow the commander's orders that much; instead you think you could do more damage by leading a strike squad to that isolated base over there. From an expendable troop to a valuable leader - that's where the beauty of this game lies. Another important piece of this game lies in the RP (Resource Points) system. Using resource points, you can change your equipment as well as call down support from HQ in the form of artillery, paratroopers, etc. Getting RP requires you to gather information on enemy vehicles, capture territory, and safely delivering that chewing gum you found back to base. But the most important thing to remember about RWR is that it's all about tactics. If you and the enemy are locked in a stalemate, maybe you should try flanking them while they're preoccupied with your allies. If you've got a silenced weapon, put that to use by sneaking into the enemy base unaware. For an kinda silly game, RWR is perhaps one of the best war simulations to have ever been created.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One of the most exciting games to come out of Greenlight in awhile. RWR is a top-down tactical shooter with incredibly high AI populations and a one-of-many mentality that keeps you moving from cover to cover, instead of blazing through running and gunning. The maps are expansive, well populated, and pretty. Everything in this game is largely polished, keeping in mind that it IS still in beta.

Most importantly, the developers keep an incredibly close dialogue with us Beta players through the forums and server play. As a player suggesting changes, it feels like the devs are really listening! (often giving you direct feedback in the forums lettign you know whether your suggestions are feasible).

Running with Rifles is a game to keep your eye on, as it only gets better with each update!

reviewText: I found the one game I never knew I had wanted. This game is for anyone who has had that want/need to find a game where you are NOT the hero or more important character in the game. You are literally placed on the same level with the obviously really stupid AI soldiers that you happen to fight with. You will have to work and do things that actually contribute to the battle in order to gain any XP and the XP rewarded is not given freely. I like the fact that after 2 hours of fighting I am only ranked a Corporal or a Sargeant. You will be given the option to preform behind enemy line missions of assasinating/knifing(for more XP) enemy officers(who actually looks different then the grunts that he happens to be leading in a flank or a big push up the middle. You could also go and destroy enemy structures like fuel, water, raid stashes, etc etc. Or you can jump into the grinder and die many times as you assault the enemy's line probing for a weakness or hole. Also vehicles feel overpowered(mowing down infantry foolish enough to leave themselves exposed for a second or two and can be destroy with 2 or 3 rockets(depending on where you hit them). This game will take a few hours to get down the whole line of sight, cover, terran and which weapons/faction suits your playstyle that makes it feel like a different battle every time I have played. (3 different battles on the same map felt different as the starting postitions are seem random and the bots don't act the same every battle.)

reviewText:
This game is Epic. It's like the little toy soldiers game you played when you were little, with the little plastic green army dudes, remember? Only now, you control one!

So eh.. ..I consider myself to be adequate at shooters.. but with this wonderful game I stand no chance whatsoever.
:D
That means I have to be tactical about it, and my tactics basicly consist of doing a Leeeroy.. !

Eventhough my tactics are pretty lousy, this game is addictive as hell. The balance and game mechanics are superb. You have total sandbox freedom, but if u suck, u suck, and u wont get anything done. So better acquaint yourself with tactics that outclass mine or Leroy's. ;) Oh and don't forget that funky feel this game has, which kind of reminds me of Worms. Especially the nades and the little textbubbles.
This game deserves more attention. So much more that it got me to write this review, hoping It'll convince a few of you.

Hoping to see you all on the fields of battle soon!

reviewText:
Let me tell you how i spent my first couple of hours playing this game:
'Heeey, a top-down shooter. Let's give it a try.' - i said.
Where is where? Is there a map? - BOOM - i'm dead.
Damn where am i aiming? And how can i jump? Okay, everything is clear - aaand i'm dead.
I see the enemy! - i'm dead. They saw me too.
I see the enemy! Okay, i take cover. GRENADE!! - i'm dead.
WHAT? Enemy blowed my cover. What's that? A grenade? Are the boxes destructable??? *BOOM*
Hey, i got a grenade. Accidentally drop it. *BOOM* - i'm dead.
Friendly fire - i'm dead...

...and it went like this...

But i found it very exciting, despite the fact that each soldier i controlled spent only ~1-2 minutes alive.
After a while i learned this 'n' that:
- not to take unnecessary risks, try not to die;
- there is nothing such like safe spot"
- move your ♥♥♥ 'cause the next grenade is maybe on it's way to your exact position;
- never rush alone;
- ALWAYS try to take cover
date: and\n- take everything you can to your stash
recommended: you can sort the goods later
hoursPlayed:
things like that.

Good choice to buy!"

reviewText:
EDIT: The game is still good, but the community is lackluster and the servers more unstable than ever. After RWR left Early Access I played a game in which none of these newcomers wanted to actually complete maps, just sit around and farm rare weapons, like it was the point of the game.

If you just play the game normally, you get plenty of rare items, there is no reason to do something as boring as farm items. What made it worse was the hijacking of crucial vehicles to do their farming. It's bad enough they didn't want to complete the map, but they prevented others from completing the map.

If item farming is your thing, go right ahead. But the community here has gotten nasty.

**********************************************************
Traded in a porn mag for weapons & grenades. 9/10



On a more serious and thorough note, this game has quite a bit of potential. Right now, it's somewhat prone to lag and desync errors, and the NYC server is unstable and probably in desperate need of a reboot, but the game itself is quite challenging and entertaining... even more so when pvp. And the fact that aimbots count for nothing is rather endearing. No matter how well you aim
date:
your soldier may not be as accurate as you are, and your weapon may have more spray and recoil than you'd like.

Ultimately, this game will teach you some core basics that any actual soldier knows very well: (1) Cover is King, (2) Flank the enemy if you want to eliminate him fast and with minimal casualties, (3) Sometimes the only way to proceed is with heavy weapons support [i.e. tanks or artillery].

There is a lot of potential for expansion. I'd love to see air support added (not just paratroopers, maybe smart bomb strikes that are always on-target and arrive quickly). I think the AA guns are a cool mechanic, but it would be awesome if they were a deployable that could shoot down enemy reinforcements, perhaps like a mortar you could hop in one and shoot down planes via a special interface.

And I know they have the mines and tank traps disabled by default, but perhaps they could be deployables via some sort of engineering tool that could also fix tanks and other vehicles. The inclusion of an engineer tool would drastically change the dynamic of the game. You would actually see damaged vehicles retreat instead of the kamikaze charges they make when the vehicle reaches <20%.

Lastly, I think they could borrow and modify an idea from Battlefield. I feel like it'd be neat if a high ranking player, perhaps at least a Captain or Master Sergeant, could request a Supply Drop. It would parachute in and work like an Armory, but only for a certain amount of exchanges, and you can only buy at it, not sell. Or maybe you have to pay for everything inside it upon requisitioning it, and then it works like a public mini-stash. And it would be very, very destroyable, so you wouldn't want to do it in combat. The only reason I mention this is that on some maps, you have a severe tactical disadvantage of having no nearby armories. It gets to the point where I regularly stash equipment in my stash because there's a better chance of a stash being nearby a crucial point. A supply drop mechanic would alleviate this and reduce the frustration of some players who are stuck without AT weapons and the enemy is just going to town with a tank or two.

The game is still in Early Access, and I expect great things from it. Even if nothing more is added, it's a great game with balance and it forces you to react and think on your feet. Innovative strategies are rewarded and thinking outside the box can win the day. Give it a shot. I'd say two gamers in three will enjoy this game.

Worth buying if you can get it on sale or are OK with the asking price.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I usually don't write reviews with such a relatively small amount of time invested into the game, but I feel this game deserves it (also realizing that I can add to or subtract from it as the game develops).

It IS in early access so it currently sits in an incomplete state.

------SIMPLE OVERVIEW------
The primary way of playing RWR right now is through the campaign. Here's what happens throughout the game. You spawn on a map, a very large map. You are a grunt in an army of hundreds of other grunts. You are not some super soldier able to waltz through and take on the entire enemy army. You are simply a lowly soldier following orders. At least at first. Killing enemies gets you xp which will rank you up as you play. This xp is persistent throughout the campaign. Getting ranked up allows you to attach 1 more ally to your own squad up to a max of 10 (at the moment). Once you reach a certain rank, you get a radio that you can use to call in paratrooper support, artillery, vehicles, etc. The higher your rank, the more available calls you have.  You use the game currency" to "buy" these calls: RP or Resource Points. Resource points are obtained by capturing objective locations or completing side objectives or picking up and selling both gear and rare item drops from fallen enemies at the friendly armory on the map. Theat typical way you complete a mission is by capturing all areas on the map. Once that is done
date: extraction points open up to neighboring maps (you can see them in the top right of the current-map screen by pressing tab). The campaign as of right now is essentially to take control of all of these maps.\n\nAlso
recommended: death is inevitable. When you die
hoursPlayed:
you can either press space to spawn at the nearest spaw point or bring up the map to click on a spawn point manually (little yellow dots). Dying will remove a small amount of xp and rp. Also...your soldier gets a new name every time you respawn (not the same as your username in multiplayer) really adding to the feel that your just one disposable soldier among hundreds.

------------

That being said
voteText: I THOROUGHLY enjoy this game. Here's why:\n\n-PICK UP AND PLAY: The game's save system is quick and easy
helpfulPercent: and loading a save brings you literally right back to the moment you press "save and quit". The gameplay is simple and addictive.\n\n-DEEP GAMEPLY: Just because it's simple doesn't mean it isn't deep. This game is highly tactical and gets you thinking about how you will approach the objective both immediate and in the larger strategy being given to you by the commander who issues orders for the army
votesHelpful: marking the next capture location on the map and the direction from which you will be assaulting. The depth of tactical choices to be made is compounded by your quite apparent mortality. You die very easily. Technically you have "1" health
votesTotal: but a more accurate way to put it is that each weapon has a certain kill percentage. In other words
votesFunny: each bullet that travels out of your gun has a certain percentage to be a lethal bullet. If that hits you
commentsCount: you're immediately dead. This can be temporarily circumvented by purchasing vests at an armory
column16: but nevertheless you die very easily. Tactics are of utmost importance. The simple run and gun method does not work in this game. Again
column17: this is because you are simply one among hundreds just like you.\n\n- HUGE MAPS: This may seem trivial
column18: but I find the maps to be extremely good. There is constant fighting in different critical locations across the map
column19: and you aren't "forced" to go to the location that the commander AI has marked on your map (though the majority of your forces will go there). You most definitely don't feel constricted to a single tactic in any given skirmish on the map.\n\n- CHARM COMIN' OUT THE EARS: This game's style is simply fantastic. The soldiers are made of little voxels and the overall feel of the game comes across as somewhat cartoony
column20: but still has a kind of gritty and realistic feel while your playing. I think this is because the shapes are simple and so seem a bit cartoony
column21: but the color palettes and lighting are very realistic. Not only that
column22: but the battlefield changes as you play. Blood will start to stain the ground more where prolonged fights have taken place. Explosions leave grungy textures behind. Car wreckages from exploded vehicles begin to populate the field. It's really awesome to be on a map for a long time and see it change as you play.\n\n- ABOVE AVERAGE AI: I don't say this in a sweeping statement
column23: but when it comes to fights they are fairly competent. With maps so large and with tactics being so necessary to success
column24: the enemy really puts up a fantastic fight. It is definitely not an easy task to successfully conquer an entire map
column25: especially in 3-way battles. They have their flaws
column26: but overall the AI has a lot going for it so far.\n\n-BEST POTENTIAL FOR MULTIPLAYER I'VE SEEN IN A WHILE: The player base is simply not there yet (though there is usually one pretty populated server going most of the time with around 20-40 players in it [pvp still with a couple hundred AI as well])
column27: but man if it ever does get there...wow. Having that large of a scale of "mini-war" (seems like everything gives a neat 'tiny' feel in the game) with the amount of available tactics to each human player would be simply beyond fun. Basically imagine an RTS without base building and one person is controlling each unit manually and with no boring simple right clicking (i.e. - keyboard and mouse moving and shooting). I have played a touch of multiplayer (currently bad internet :() and it was pretty fantastic! Anyway
column28: it has amazing potential.\n\n-VERY MOD FRIENDLY: It doesn't have Steam Workshop support yet
column29: but mods are already coming out. Some really neat ones
column30: too. Someone has a mod that replaces some gun models with Warhammer 40k bolters. There's also someone working on a zombie survival mod as well. Maps can also be created by the community! The game is going to heavily support mods. Any game that does that always adds so much time to its lifespan and the community almost always ends up improving the game.\n\n-DEVS ARE SUPER FRIENDLY
column32:
AND CONTINUOUSLY REPLY TO MOST COMMUNITY POSTS: 'Nuff said.
------------

Here are some negatives:

- AI DRIVING/SOMETIMES PATHING: The AI simply cannot drive vehicles well at all. You don't want to be a passenger when the AI is driving. Their pathing is generally igood
column33: but they don't handle ladders well. This can create a problem on limiting tactics on certain areas of certain maps
column34: but this is VERY VERY VERY few and far between. Regardless
column35: the AI can still be a bit wonky with ladders.\n\n- CAN NOT DIRECTLY CONTROL THE FLOW OF BATTLE: When the AI commander marks a new capture objective
column36: the majority of your allies will assault that location and you can't change it. So if you think capturing a certain other location would serve better strategic purpose
column37: it will be a lot more difficult to capture that location as the vast majority of your forces will be going where the AI commander marked. You can make it easier
column39: very expensive through spending a LOT of RP on paratrooper reinforcement squads of 8 or 4.  This isn't ALL bad as I have personally made some strategic decisions with regards to capture order that was against the order of the AI commander and successfully pulled them off tactically speaking
column42:
did actually help my team out greatly as it put us in a better position.

- CAN NOT PLAY AS OTHER FACTIONS IN CAMPAIGN MODE RIGHT NOW: Fortunately this will be added...I think in the next patch (o.96) even..

-MULTIPLAYER PLAYER-BASE NOT VERY LARGE: D:

------CLOSING------

I close with the mention of a small multiplayer player-base because the only way for it to grow is if someone like you

reviewText:
This game is great, i can only recommend this game with no reason to even dislike the game. The campaigns are great fun and can be extremely hard with different setting ( for example setting enemy accuracy to %100 - original is %94).

Multiplayer is even better with a great tactical community that you can only love, one of the key features in RwR is gaining xp and ranking up to recieve a promotion, every time you get promoted you get RP which acts as currency -(there are other means of earing RP which i wont go over as there are great in game guides). You also get more squad mates, who follow you around helping you.

There is so much more to go over but all i can say is this game is amazing, GET IT!

reviewText: It looks like a fast paced arcade shooter, but it really is a rather careful game where if you step even too far around the corner, someone will shoot your foot twice and you will instantly drop dead. An excellent game for its price, RWR has more challenge than you'd expect.
